newsitem.title: INDIA: Delhi shares bounce off lows on fund buying.
newsitem.headline: Delhi shares bounce off lows on fund buying.

text.p: Late session buying by domestic financial institutions offset the dampening effect of U.S. missile strikes on Iraq and drove share prices to a higher close in Delhi, brokers said.
The Delhi Stock Exchange's sensitive index closed 2.37 points higher at 792.05. At mid-session the index was 788.87.
Brokers said foreign institutional investors stayed on the sidelines following the news of further U.S. missile attacks on Iraq.

The United States fired a second round of missiles at targets in southern Iraq on Wednesday and enforced a wider no-fly zone, pursuing one of its most serious confrontations with President Saddam Hussein since the Gulf War in 1991.
Iraq said one person was killed and seven were wounded.
Reliance Industries edged up 0.30 rupee to 209.15, while TISCO dropped 0.35 rupee to 195.35.
State Bank of India was up 0.75 rupee to 278.50 while Oriental Bank of Commerce gained 0.10 rupee to 90.90.
The Delhi Stock Exchange will remain closed on Thursday for the Hindu festival of Janmashtami, bourse officials said.
